abstracts.cdata!:
This Sectoral Environmental Assessment
            (SEA) for the Water Sector Adjustment Loan describes the
            risks associated with Indonesia's policy reforms
            regarding water management, and it proposes mitigation
            options. The lack of transparency and accountability will be
            offset by encouraging nongovernmental organizations to act
            as permanent advisory members to the national apex body that
            will be established to address the overall weakness in
            implementing environmental regulations. The participation of
            stakeholders will also be increased through strengthening
            provincial and river basin water resources management
            agencies, committees, and units. To address water pollution,
            particularly urban pollution from household waste and
            agricultural chemicals, long-term programs of institutional
            and infrastructure development and training and promotion
            programs (e.g., integrated pest management and frequent
            media campaigns) will be installed. To allay concerns about
            the capacity of water users' associations to handle
            irrigation reform and the transfer of secondary canals, and
            about the varying patterns of community leadership between
            the regions, a recommendation was made to phase in these
            responsibilities while continuously reviewing and revising
            the transfer procedure.
